readingPart.reading:
adrenal cortexpancreastestis
adrenal medullaparathyroidthyroid
ovarypituitary (hypophysis)

questionContent.questionText:
1. behind the stomach [pancreas]

2. posterior side of the thyroid gland [parathyroid]

3. inner section of glands above each kidney [adrenal medulla]

4. in the scrotal sac [testis]

5. on either side of the trachea [thyroid gland]

6. outer section of gland above each kidney [adrenal cortex]

7. lower abdomen of a female [ovary]

8. below the brain in the sella turcica [pituitary (hypophysis)]

instructions.instructions: Match the endocrine gland with its location.

questionContent.questionText:
1. follicle-stimulating hormone [anterior pituitary gland]

2. vasopressin [posterior pituitary gland]

3. aldosterone [adrenal cortex]

4. insulin [beta islet cells of the pancreas]

5. thyroxine [thyroid gland]

6. cortisol [adrenal cortex]

7. gonadotropic hormones [anterior pituitary gland]

8. epinephrine [adrenal medulla]

9. oxytocin [posterior pituitary gland]

10. prolactin [anterior pituitary gland]

11. growth hormone [anterior pituitary gland]

12. glucagon [alpha islet cells of the pancreas]

13. adrenocorticotropic hormone [anterior pituitary gland]

14. estradiol [ovaries]

15. progesterone [ovaries]

16. testosterone [testes]

17. thyroid-stimulating hormone [anterior pituitary gland]

instructions.instructions: Name the endocrine organs (including the appropriate lobe or region) that produce the following hormones

questionContent.questionText:
1. ADH [antidiuretic hormone]

2. ACTH [adrenocorticotropic hormone]

3. LH [luteinizing hormone]

4. FSH [follicle-stimulating hormone]

5. TSH [thyroid-stimulating hormone]

6. PTH [parathyroid hormone]

7. GH [growth hormone]

8. PRL [prolactin]

9. T4 [thyroxine/tetraiodothyronine]

10. T3 [triiodothyronine]

11. OT [oxytocin]

12. HCG [human chorionic gonadotropin ]

instructions.instructions: Spell out the following abbreviations for hormones.

readingPart.reading:
ACTHepinephrineparathyroid hormone
ADHestradioltestosterone
aldosteroneinsulinthyroxine
cortisol

questionContent.questionText:
1. sympathomimetic; raises heart rate and blood pressure [epinephrine]

2. promotes growth and maintenance of male sex characteristics [testosterone]

3. stimulates water reabsorption by kidney tubules; decreases urine output [ADH]

4. increases metabolism in body cells [thyroxine]

5. raises blood calcium [parathyroid hormone]

6. increases reabsorption of sodium by kidney tubules [aldosterone]

7. stimulates secretion of hormones from the adrenal cortex [ACTH]

8. increases blood sugar [cortisol]

9. helps transport glucose to cells; decreases blood sugar [insulin]

10. develops and maintains female sex characteristics [estradiol ]

Condition

1. Cushing syndrome [hypersecretion/hyposecretion]
2. tetany [hyposecretion/hypersecretion]
3. Graves disease [hypersecretion/hyposecretion] 
4. diabetes insipidus [hyposecretion/hypersecretion] 
5. acromegaly [hypersecretion/hyposecretion] 
6. myxedema [hyposecretion/hypersecretion] 
7. diabetes mellitus [hyposecretion/hypersecretion] 
8. Addison disease [hyposecretion/hypersecretion] 
9. gigantism [hypersecretion/hyposecretion] 
10. endemic goiter [hyposecretion/hypersecretion] 
11. cretinism [hyposecretion/hypersecretion] 
12. pheochromocytoma [hypersecretion/hyposecretion]

instructions.instructions: Indicate whether the following conditions are related to hypersecretion or hyposecretion.

readingPart.reading:
adenohypophysispancreas
adrenal cortexparathyroid gland
adrenal medullatestes
neurohypophysisthyroid
ovaries

questionContent.questionText:
Condition
1. Cushing syndrome [adrenal cortex]
2. tetany [parathyroid gland]
3. Graves disease [thyroid gland]
4. diabetes insipidus [neurohypophysis] 
5. acromegaly [adenohypophysis]
6. myxedema [thyroid gland]
7. diabetes mellitus [pancreas]
8. Addison disease [adrenal cortex]
9. gigantism [adenohypophysis]
10. endemic goiter [thyroid gland]
11. cretinism [thyroid gland]
12. pheochromocytoma [adrenal medulla]

instructions.instructions: Select from the following the endocrine glands involved in each disease.

readingPart.reading:
ADHGH
aldosteroneinsulin
cortisolparathyroid hormone
epinephrinethyroxine

questionContent.questionText:
Condition
1. Cushing syndrome [cortisol]
2. tetany [parathyroid hormone]
3. Graves disease [thyroxine]
4. diabetes insipidus [ADH]
5. acromegaly [GH]
6. myxedema [thyroxine]
7. diabetes mellitus [insulin]
8. Addison disease [aldosterone and cortisol]
9. gigantism [GH]
10. endemic goiter [thyroxine]
11. cretinism  [thyroxine]
12. pheochromocytoma [epinephrine]

instructions.instructions: Select from the following the hormones involved in each disease.

questionContent.questionText:
1. removal of the pancreas: [pancreat]ectomy

2. condition of deﬁciency or underdevelopment of the sex organs: hypo[gonadism]

3. pertaining to producing female (characteristics): [estro]genic

4. removal of the pituitary gland: [hypophys]ectomy

5. deﬁciency of calcium in the blood: hypo[calcemia]

6. excessive sugar in the blood: [hyperglyc]emia

7. inﬂammation of the thyroid gland: [thyroid]itis

8. specialist in the study of hormone disorders: [endocrinolog]ist

instructions.instructions: Build medical terms based on the deﬁnitions and word parts given.

readingPart.reading: deﬁcient sodium in the blood
condition of excessive thirst
excessive potassium in the blood
excessive calcium in the blood
deﬁcient sugar in the blood
condition of sugar in the urine
normal thyroid function
condition of increased secretion from the thyroid gland
constant muscle contraction (result of hypoparathyroidism)
condition of excessive ketones (acids) in the blood as a result of diabetes mellitus

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following conditions.

readingPart.reading: the male and female sex organs (ovaries and testes); examples of gonadotropins are FSH and LH
bones; another name for somatotropin is growth hormone
thyroid gland; another name for thyrotropin is thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)
adrenal cortex; another name for adrenocorticotropin is adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)

instructions.instructions: The following hormones are all produced by the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland (note that they all have the same sufﬁx, -tropin). Name the target tissue they act on or stimulate in the body.

readingPart.reading: complex substances derived from cholesterol; hormones from the adrenal cortex and sex hormonesare steroids
complex substances derived from an amino acid; epinephrine (adrenaline) and norepinephrine (noradrenaline) are examples
anterior lobe of the pituitary gland
continuous contractions of muscles associated with low levels of parathyroid hormone
eyeballs that bulge outward; associated with hyperthyroidism
steroid hormones from the adrenal cortex (outer region of the adrenal gland) that inﬂuence salt (minerals such as sodium and potassium) metabolism
tendency of an organism to maintain a constant internal environment
substance that mimics the action of the sympathetic nerves; epinephrine (adrenaline) is an example
steroid hormones from the adrenal cortex that inﬂ uence sugar metabolism in the body
catecholamine hormone from the adrenal medulla; adrenaline
animal starch; storage form of glucose
male hormone; testosterone is an example
hormone secreted by the adrenal cortex; cortisol is an example
hormone from the posterior lobe of the pituitary that stimulates contraction of the uterus during labor
major hormone from the thyroid gland; thyroxine (contains four iodine atoms)
abnormal secretion of androgens from the adrenal cortex produces masculine characteristics in a female
cancerous tumor of the thyroid gland
excessive hair on the body (result of excessive secretion of androgens)
enlargement of extremities (excessive secretion of growth hormone after puberty)
female hormone; an estrogen

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following medical terms.

readingPart.reading: destruction of the beta cells (islets of Langerhans); insulin is not produced
destruction of nerves as a secondary complication of diabetes mellitus

abnormal condition of high levels of ketones (acids) in the blood as a result of improper burning of fats; fats are burned because the cells do not have sugar available as a result of lack of insulin or inability of insulin to act
too little sugar in the blood; this can occur if too much insulin is taken by a diabetic patient
insulin deﬁciency and resistance by target tissue to the action of insulin
destruction of blood vessels in the retina as a secondary complication of diabetes mellitus
unconsciousness caused by high levels of sugar in the blood; water leaves cells to balance the large amounts of sugar in the blood, leading to cellular dehydration
destruction of the kidneys as a secondary complication of diabetes mellitus
collection of fatty plaque in arteries
high level of sugar in the blood; insulin is unavailable or unable to transport sugar from the blood into cells
decreased gastric motility (-paresis means slight paralysis); secondary complication of diabetes
hypoglycemic shock caused by an overdose of insulin, decreased intake of food, or excessive exercise

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms related to diabetes mellitus.

readingPart.reading: Radioactive compound is given, and the thyroid gland is imaged using a scanning device
Measurement of blood sugar levels in a fasting patient (at least 4 hours) and after intervals of 30 minutes and 1, 2, and 3 hours after ingestion of glucose
Measurement of eyeball protrusion (symptom of Graves disease)
Measurement of T3, T4, and TSH in the bloodstream

instructions.instructions: Explain the following laboratory tests or clinical procedures related to the endocrine system

questionContent.questionText:
1. Phyllis was diagnosed with Graves disease when her husband noticed her [exophthalmos/panhypopituitarism/hirsutism]. Her eyes seemed to be bulging out of their sockets.

2. Helen had a primary brain tumor called a [pituitary/thyroid/adrenal] adenoma. Her entire endocrine system was disrupted, and her physician recommended surgery and radiation therapy to help relieve her symptoms.

3. Bessie’s facial features gradually became “rough” in her late thirties and forties. By the time she was 50, her adult children noticed her very large hands and recommended that she see an endocrinologist, who diagnosed her chronically progressive condition as [acromegaly/hyperinsulism/gigantism].

4. Bobby was brought into the emergency department because he was found passed out in the kitchen. He had not taken his usual dose of insulin and had developed [diabetic ketoacidosis/Cushing disease/hyperparathyroidism].

5. Because her 1-hour test of blood sugar was slightly abnormal, Selma’s obstetrician ordered a [glucose tolerance test/thyroid function test/Pap smear] to rule out gestational [diabetes/hyperthyroidism/chlamydial infection].  

6. Bill noticed that he was passing his urine more frequently, a condition known as [polyuria/polyphagia/hyperglycemia], and was experiencing increased thirst, manifested as [polydipsia/hypernatremia/polyphagia]. His wife urged him to see a physician, who performed a [urinalysis/serum calcium test/serum sodium test] that revealed inappropriately dilute [urine/blood/sweat]. Measurement of the hormone [ADH/PTH/HCG] in his blood showed low levels. His diagnosis was [DI/DM/SIADH]. Treatment with [vasopressin/oxytocin/cortisol] delivered by nasal spray was prescribed, and his condition improved.

7. Mary noticed that she had gained weight recently and that her face had a moon-like fullness with new heavy hair growth. Her blood pressure was high at her doctor’s appointment. Blood and urine tests showed high levels of blood sugar and [cortisol/vasopressin/thyroid hormone]. Her diagnostic workup included a/an [CT scan of the abdomen/thyroid ultrasound/thyroid scan], which revealed a tumor in the [adrenal gland/pancreas/thyroid gland]. Her doctor made the diagnosis of [Cushing syndrome/hyperthyroidism/Addison disease].

8. Jack had several fractures of ribs and vertebrae in a skiing accident. X-ray images of his bones revealed a generalized decrease in bone density, a condition known as [osteoporosis/tetany/acromegaly]. A blood test showed high serum [calcium/sodium/growth hormone] and high levels of [parathyroid hormone/mineralocorticoids/somatotropin]. An ultrasound scan of the neck revealed a [parathyroid/thymus/thyroid] adenoma, which was removed surgically. His bone disease and other abnormalities were all related to [hyperparathyroidism/hypoparathyroidism/hypothyroidism].

instructions.instructions: Select the terms that best complete the meaning of the sentences.
